column2: Enforce Foundational Controls (MFA & Encryption). Mandate Multi-Factor Authentication for remote access and AES-256 encryption for data at rest.
column3: Deficient Foundational Security Controls. Lack of basic hygiene allowed attackers easy entry and readable data access.
column4: Prevented the initial credential theft and made the exfiltrated patient data unreadable/useless to attackers.
column5: Critical Compliance: Directly addresses HIPAA requirements for protecting patient data (PH) and prevents massive regulatory fines.

column2: Deploy Immutable Backup Strategy. Implement the 3-2-1 rule with offline/immutable storage that cannot be altered or deleted.
column3: Insufficient Backup & Recovery. Backups were accessible and deletable by the attackers, forcing a ransom payment
column4: Would have allowed RCI to restore operations immediately without paying the ransom or losing data.
column5: Business Continuity: Ensures the hospital can continue saving lives during a cyberattack without financial extortion.

column2: Formalize IT Governance & Risk Register. Create a risk register requiring executive sign-off and updated Incident Response Plans (IRP).
column3: Ineffective Governance. Leadership hid the breach and lacked a plan, increasing legal liability.
column4: Prevented the chaotic, illegal response and the "cover-up" attempt by the CFO.
column5: Legal Liability: Protects the brand reputation and executives from negligence lawsuits or jail time.

column2: Deploy Centralized Monitoring (SIEM/NIDS). Implement a system to aggregate logs and detect network intrusions in real-time.
column3: Lack of Monitoring. RCI was "blind" to the attackers moving through the network for days.
column4: Would have alerted IT to the initial intrusion attempts, allowing containment before encryption occurred.
column5: Operational Insight: Reduces "dwell time" (time hackers are inside), minimizing damage and investigation costs.

column2: Implement Automated Asset Discovery. Deploy tools to continuously map all hardware and software on the network.
column3: Lack of Asset Inventory. "Shadow IT" and unmanaged devices created open doors for attackers.
column4: Would have identified the vulnerable, unpatched server used as the entry point.
column5: Cost Control: Eliminates waste on unused software and ensures 100% of assets are secured.

column2: Establish Vulnerability Management Program. Schedule weekly automated scans and annual third-party penetration tests.
column3: Absence of Audit Schedule. Vulnerabilities piled up because nobody was checking for them.
column4: Would have flagged the specific software flaw the attackers exploited to gain entry.
column5: Proactive Defense: Finds and fixes holes before criminals can exploit them, maintaining system integrity.
